New York University Abu Dhabi Library
Mediterranean Pilgrimage Association - Hisham Khatib Collection
Khatib, Hisham, Mr.
AD.MC.030_ref150
131 Leaves - One album containing postcards, tourism booklets, tickets and a cruise itinerary and berthing list.
1928 Generally good, some brittle and warped. The Mediterranean Pilgrimage Association album contains postcards from a cruise on the S.S. Umbria (SITMAR line – Societa Italiana di Servizi Marittimi) that left London on the 27th April 1928. The postcards are mainly from Egypt, Palestine and Turkey.
The Hisham Khatib Collection on the Holy Land and region is one of the largest collections of Middle Eastern photography still in private hands. It contains hundreds of 19th century original albumen photographic prints as well as many travel albums of the same period and early 20th century with hundreds of black and white photographs and postcards. The collection contains photography from dozens of photographers, but the albumen prints are mostly the work of the Bonfils family, Francis Frith, Francis Bedford, Matson photo Service, American Colony, Zangaki Brothers, and Frank Mason Good. Dr. Hisham Khatib has spent over 40 years amassing a vast and historically valuable collection of representations of the Near East, including the Holy Lands, including Palestine, Jordan, Turkey, Syria and Egypt. The artworks in this extraordinary collection include paintings, prints, maps, books, photographs, as well as postcards. A large part of Dr. Khatib's collection consists of rare photographic prints: he has over 3,000 images. See main collection http://dlib.nyu.edu/findingaids/html/akkasah/ad_mc_030/ Digital copy only: ad_mc_030_ref150
Content Description
The Mediterranean Pilgrimage Association album contains postcards from a cruise on the S.S. Umbria (SITMAR line – Societa Italiana di Servizi Marittimi) that left London on the 27th April 1928. The postcards are mainly from Egypt, Palestine and Turkey.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Dr. Hisham Khatib are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from repository. Please contact Akkasah at akkasah@nyu.edu
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
